title-group.article-title: Challenges faced by healthcare providers in implementing preconception care for women with diabetes in public health clinics in Malaysia – A qualitative study

sec.title: Background
sec.p: In Malaysia, diabetes in pregnancy poses a significant challenge. If uncontrolled, it leads to unfavourable maternal and foetal outcomes. Preconception care offers healthcare providers and women with diabetes an opportunity to minimise risk factors before pregnancy. However, the utilisation of this service in the public health clinics remains limited. This study aimed to explore the challenges experienced by healthcare providers in implementing preconception care for women with diabetes.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This was a qualitative study that employed a single case study approach. Participants were purposely recruited for focus group discussions and in-depth interviews. An interview guide, developed based on the Theoretical Domain Framework, was used. All interviews were conducted at four public health clinics in a state with a high prevalence of diabetes in Malaysia. Interviews were audio-recorded and transcribed verbatim. The transcripts were then analysed through thematic analysis, using a reflexive approach with an inductive strategy. Ethical approval was obtained from the Medical Research Ethics Committee, Ministry of Health Malaysia.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Fifty-three healthcare providers involved in preconception care were interviewed. Three major themes affecting the provision and delivery of preconception care for women with diabetes were identified: (1) Systemic and organisational barriers which create foundational barriers, (2) Healthcare provider factors which affect frontline implementation, and (3) Patient-related factors which influence the engagement of women with diabetes in utilising preconception care. This study identifies gaps within healthcare systems and providers, as well as factors influencing women with diabetes that need to be addressed for effective implementation of preconception care.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study offers insights into the challenges of implementing preconception care effectively. Within the healthcare system, instead of segregating management within similar healthcare facilities, consolidating resources could address manpower and infrastructure challenges. Providing comprehensive training for healthcare providers is crucial to improve care quality and health literacy among women with diabetes. Successful implementation relies on effective engagement between healthcare providers and the women. In this way, preconception care can be recognised as an essential component of the diabetes management pathway within the healthcare system in the country.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s12875-025-02991-y.

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Background
sec.p: In Malaysia, diabetes presents a significant public health challenge due to its high prevalence and increasing trend. It adversely impacts the quality of life, placing a considerable burden on healthcare systems and contributing to economic challenges. The National Health and Morbidity Survey 2023 reported that 15.6%, or one in six adults, in Malaysia has diabetes [1, 2]. The incidence of diabetes in pregnancy (DIP) is also alarming, exhibiting a consistent upward trend, increasing from 14.8% in 2018 to 18.1% in 2019 and reaching 21.9% in 2020 [3]. DIP poses risks to both the mother and the developing foetus, significantly affecting pregnancy outcomes. In Malaysia, the prevalence of DIP-related stillbirth rose from 7.55 in 2013 to 19.6 in 2015 [3], and approximately 10% of DIP cases result in congenital malformations, particularly when glucose levels remain uncontrolled [2]. In comparison to normal pregnancy, DIP also resulted in a higher rate of instrumental and caesarean deliveries [3]. Gestational diabetes (GDM) accounts for the most significant proportion of DIP, reported at approximately 22% of diabetes in Malaysia [3]. Pregestational diabetes (PGD) constitutes a smaller proportion, yet it has a considerable impact. It is documented that the pregnancy rates among women with PGD have increased from 0.30% in 2019 to 0.34% in 2020 [3]. Obstetricians strongly recommend that mothers with PGD carefully plan their pregnancies. Women with diabetes should attain optimal diabetes management before conceiving to secure favourable outcomes. It is essential for them to obtain preconception care (PCC), more importantly, to manage their blood glucose and weight effectively before beginning their pregnancy journey.

PCC aims to improve maternal and child health outcomes by enhancing the health status of both parents. It offers biomedical, behavioural and social health interventions from before conception [4]. An important strategy to reduce adverse health outcomes from DIP is adequate pregnancy planning. Although PCC provides family doctors and their patients with an opportunity to discuss and mitigate risk factors before pregnancy, more than 60% of deceased mothers did not utilise family planning intended to optimise their blood glucose levels before conceiving [5]. Given the high diabetes burden in the country, PCC in Malaysia has largely targeted mothers or women with chronic medical illnesses [6]. In Malaysia, women of reproductive age with diabetes who do not intend to conceive or have not achieved an optimal metabolic environment to conceive are usually offered family planning by the PCC clinic [6]. Even though women with high-risk pregnancies who use family planning are expected to be more likely to undergo PCC, the overall utilisation of this service remains low [7]. The prevalence of family planning use among women with diabetes varied, ranging from 4.8 to 89.8% [8]. Women with diabetes were reported to be less likely to utilise any family planning methods compared to women without diabetes mellitus (8). These are individuals who are most in need of PCC but are often the least likely to receive counselling in PCC [9]. Healthcare providers (HCPs) have also observed that this service is suboptimally delivered [10]. The uptake of pre-pregnancy care clinics was reported to be low among women with high-risk pregnancies, including those with diabetes, a state located north of Peninsular Malaysia [7]. The low use of family planning services and pre-pregnancy care clinics among these women brings up important questions about how well PCC is being implemented in Malaysia. The increasing prevalence of DIP in Malaysia represents a significant concern that necessitates a multifaceted approach to both prevention and management. In this context, addressing this issue through preconception care as a preparatory measure before pregnancy is of utmost importance.

Many studies have identified the factors influencing the utilisation of PCC among women, but limited studies have evaluated this service from the perspectives of HCPs, especially in Malaysia, where the sociocultural, religious, and demographic backgrounds of women with diabetes and HCPs vary. This study aimed to explore the challenges experienced by HCPs in implementing PCC for women with diabetes in public health clinics in Malaysia.

sec.title: Study design and participant recruitment
sec.p: This was a qualitative study that employed a single case study approach using an embedded single case design. A case study allows in-depth, multi-faceted empirical explorations of the phenomena of interest in their natural real-life settings and is particularly applicable to answer research questions pertaining to “how”, and “why” a program runs [11, 12]. This design helps to explore the challenges faced by key stakeholders that are involved in the implementation of PCC for women with diabetes, and in this context, are the healthcare providers (HCPs). The case study focuses on the PCC program in NS, Malaysia, one of the states with a high prevalence of diabetes [1]. Before the interviews began, the main author met with the clinic’s manager to ensure transparency, align mutual expectations, and identify potential participants.

Participants were purposely sampled to capture diverse perspectives. The nurses, assistant medical officers (AMOs), medical officers (MOs), diabetes educators (DEs) and Family Medicine Specialists (FMS) who were directly involved in the management of women with diabetes were invited for the study. They were from two urban and two rural public health clinics located in the state of southwest Peninsular Malaysia to explore whether locality would give a different view. All participants were assigned pseudonyms and provided with a brief overview of the study protocol via an information sheet. Verbal and written informed consent for the interview, audio recording, and observation were obtained.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: Most interviews involving nurses, AMOs, MOs, and DEs were conducted via focus group discussions (FGDs). FGDs allow interactive discussions among participants with mixed levels of knowledge and experience on the topic [9]. Each FGD consists of two to four participants. The sessions were arranged according to the availability of HCPs, resulting in fewer participants than the ideal number recommended for a focus group discussion (FGD) session. Conversely, in-depth interviews (IDIs) were conducted with the FMSs, who serve as key informants. These key informant interviews were important because in Malaysia, FMSs lead and oversee clinical care and develop the standard operating procedures for PCC in clinics. Moreover, conducting IDIs with the key informants helps mitigate the power imbalances that might influence the interviews with their subordinates, which could occur during focus group discussions (FGDs). A total of 28 MOs and FMSs were interviewed via eight FGDs and five IDIs, while 25 nurses, AMOs and DEs were interviewed via nine FGDs and one IDI. The FGDs and IDIs lasted on average 90 min and 60 min, respectively. Each participant was interviewed only once. All interviews took place over an eight-month period, from January to August 2018. The FGDs and IDIs were guided by an interview guide (Appendix A) developed based on the construct of the Theoretical Domain Framework (TDF) that was used to explain the behaviours of HCPs during various clinical practices [13]. The TDF framework specifies barriers and enablers at multiple levels, explaining the influences on implementation outcomes and the relationships between the determinants [13]. The interviews were conducted by the primary author, who was trained as a qualitative researcher. Other authors who were also qualitative researchers assisted with the analysis. To ensure the credibility of the study, the transcripts were returned to seven participants for member checks, and all participants agreed with the interpretation of their views. Interviewer bias was minimized by using a reflexivity journal and peer debriefing with the research team, ensuring data collection and analysis were not influenced by the researchers’ personal identities, background or interests. The reflexivity journal documented the interviewer’s thoughts, assumptions, and emotional reactions experienced during the interviews. The dependability of data was ensured through triangulation, involving observation field notes and relevant archival materials, such as the PCC registry, perinatal care manual, and patients’ records, to add contextual meaning to the participants’ interviews.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: The interviews were transcribed verbatim, and the detailed transcriptions were analysed using reflexive thematic analysis (RTA) [14] with an inductive strategy. The three phases were as follows: Phase 1: Familiarisation. The team members repeatedly listened to the first three recordings reviewed, reflected on the transcripts, and subsequently helped synthesise insights from the data. Field notes were also used to provide context for the data. Phase 2: Coding. An iterative process was employed, starting with descriptive coding and followed by discussions among the research team to develop shared definitions of the codes. The team used NVivo version 10 (QSR International, Burlington, Massachusetts, USA) to assist with the coding. Phase 3: Generating themes. The codes were later collated into broader themes based on similar meanings and concepts that reflected the experiences of HCPs managing women with diabetes. The codes were constantly compared across different interviews over several meetings to ascertain meanings and prevent duplication of codes and themes. Disagreements on certain codes were resolved by re-examining the meaning of the codes and referring to the objectives. Finally, the team arrived at the final themes. The COREQ checklist (Appendix B) was used to ensure the quality of reporting for this article [15].

sec.title: Ethical consideration
sec.p: Ethical approval was obtained from the Medical Research Ethics Committee [NMRR-17-1613-36439].

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 53 participants (28 were FMSs and MOs and 25 were nurses, AMOs and diabetes educators) were interviewed. Table 1 presents the demographic characteristics of the participants.

Table 2 summarises the themes, subthemes, codes and examples of quotes for this study. Thematic analysis identified three themes regarding the experiences and challenges faced by the HCPs in providing and delivering PCC to women with diabetes, namely (1) systemic and organisational barriers which create foundational barriers; (2) healthcare provider (HCP) factors which affect frontline implementation; and (3) Patient-related factors which influence the engagement of women with diabetes in utilising preconception care

caption.p: Challenges experienced by HCPs in the provision and delivery of PCC to women with diabetes

tr.td: PCC not embedded in existing diabetes programs

“Our health education in the public clinic is more towards diabetes… Only when they are pregnant will we start telling about diabetes in pregnancy…it is quite rare that we gather patients, educate them about this”
“we have it (PCC) in MCH (maternal child health) but not in OPD (out-patient department). No reproductive part there”.
Not prioritised in key performance metrics
“…it (PCC) is not a KPI (key performance indicator). The admin people only focus on HbA1c.”
Lack of a systematic medical record
“because, there’s no such template to do such thing in the computerised system, it is not designed .not specific to pre-pregnancy care in diabetes.”

td.italic: “..environment plays a role. No privacy. One room has 2 doctors..so patient is shy to to talk more about private issues”.

td.p: “for me, I have not had any training in PCC… so; I’m not very comfortable to do this kind of counselling”
“there is no guideline to assist on PCC and family planning”.
“ Sometimes, female patient requires female doctor to talk about sensitive issues. But our system doesn’t allow patients to request for doctors.”

“pregnancy planning,.it didn’t cross my mind. I will need to have a chaperon, we have barriers with that, and 9 years of experience, they have never asked me (on pregnancy), probably because they are more comfortable with female doctors. ”

tr.td: “I’m not a very patient doctor. I want to settle things very fast, sometimes maybe my voice also is not soft. I don’t get women telling me about reproductive issues.”
Influence of personal or religious beliefs
“I’m a muslim, and being a muslim, we are encouraged to have more kids. I think I’m blocking those things if I suggest ligation.”
“I’m a junior MO, so it will be a bit scary because I don’t really know, not really sure about what to do in clinic care in PCC.”
“…when a reproductive age woman came, …we either forget or miss, somehow, we tend to concentrate on why they come, (diabetes)…That is why,.we tend to miss this (PCC).”

td.p: “The nurses are not doing anything (PCC). Not here. Only the doctors.”

“sometimes PCC form came out empty. I don’t know what to say. Maybe they (doctors) wanted to be fast …the form is already clipped at the front page, maybe they just flip and see what they need to do…a lot are like that.”

tr.td: Poor pregnancy planning among women with diabetes
“despite the PCC screening, the explanation, patients still got pregnant unplanned.”

td.p: “They don’t believe in modern contraception, so they do their own protection.”
“… myth of contraception. They said, the new contraception will cause them to become infertile if taken for quite some time.”

tr.td: Impact of religious, social, and economic factors on care access

td.p: “They said that their husband disapproves (of contraception). They say children are “rezeki (gifts). No need to plan.”

“Too many follow-ups, and she cannot afford to come frequently. She’s a babysitter. So, if she wanted to come, she needs to inform all six mothers, they might find a new babysitter, she needs the money so she rather…not come.”

sec.title: 1. Theme 1: systemic and organisational barriers
sec.p: Participants revealed that, systemic and organisational barriers to implementing PCC in primary care clinics include issues related to integration deficit such as poor integration of PCC into current diabetes care models, fragmented or segregated services, inadequate medical record systems to include PCC, and a lack of emphasis on PCC in key performance indicators. These challenges are compounded by resource and infrastructure gaps, including the lack of dedicated spaces and inadequate guidance for PCC implementation. Additionally, the lack of gender-personalised care services does not fully address the needs of women with diabetes for PCC.

sec.title: PCC not embedded in existing diabetes programs
sec.p:
The existing diabetes programs did not embed PCC in the workflow. In addition, the participants revealed that the lack of priority setting by policymakers is also evident in the limited publicity or health promotion regarding PCC, both in the community and within clinics. Many educational programmes for women with diabetes are commonly centred on pregnancy and seldom include pre-pregnancy care.
“Our health education in the public clinic is more towards diabetes… Only when they are pregnant will we start telling about diabetes in pregnancy…it is quite rare that we gather patients, educate them about this.” [Dr C, FMS, rural clinic].

sec.title: Segregation of the service
sec.p:
The specialist trainees felt that the separation of physical space, workforce and delivery systems in some clinics, compared with conventional healthcare systems, contributes to the effective transfer of information regarding the reproductive backgrounds of patients. They felt that the healthcare delivery is not well integrated. The care of women with diabetes focuses mainly on managing their diabetes at the diabetes clinic while pregnancy and pre-pregnancy planning are handled at the maternal and child health clinic.
“We have it (PCC) in MCH (maternal child health) but not in OPD (out-patient department). No reproductive part there”. [Dr H, urban clinic]

The doctors realised that the lack of continuity of care resulted when care shifts from one unit (e.g. diabetes outpatient unit) to another (e.g. maternal and child health unit) even within the same clinic facility.
“There is no continuity of care because we divide our clinics into MCH and OPD. That’s why we miss some information about the patient”. [Dr I, urban clinic]

sec.title: Not prioritised in key performance metrics
sec.p:
While PCC should ideally complement the diabetes care, participants perceived PCC is given less emphasis within the diabetes programme. Thus, there is a lack of motivation to offer and promote PCC to women with diabetes, since these activities would not benefit them. Many healthcare personnel do not see PCC as an important healthcare intervention with significant implications.
"…it (PCC) is not a KPI (key performance indicator). The admin people only focus on HbA1c." [Dr P, urban clinic]
“The community, as well as the higher authority, may think that PCC is not a serious issue. With diabetic complications occurring, the cost is higher, like dialysis. But then if we don’t do PCC, they (women) just got pregnant, that is all.” [Mr Z, AMO, urban clinic].

sec.title: Lack of a systematic medical record system
sec.p:
The medical record system in Malaysia is either manual or computerised. However, the participants mentioned that the existing system does not seem to capture information on PCC comprehensively. The current manual documentation (referred to as the green book) for the care of women with diabetes includes dedicated columns for most indicators of diabetes quality, but none for reproductive indicators such as menstrual date, contraception use or family planning. Nurse A, a diabetic educator whose role is to screen these women for pregnancy risks, expressed;
“….no space to ask on family planning in the green book. I can’t say that we ask about it regularly. As humans, we may forget.” [Nurse A, rural clinic].

The provision of PCC remains opportunistic. Even in clinics with a computerised medical record system, reproductive issues were not clearly documented in the system.
“Because there’s no such template to do such a thing in the computerised system. It is not designed, nor specific to pre-pregnancy care in diabetes.” [Dr Z, urban clinic].

sec.title: Lack of a dedicated physical space for PCC
sec.p: The participants mentioned that there was no dedicated area for personalised PCC counselling. Participants felt that some patients consider discussing pregnancy as a sensitive topic, so talking about it openly might not create a suitable environment.
“ The environment plays a role. No privacy. One room has two doctors, so patient is shy to talk more about private issues”. [Nurse I, rural clinic]

sec.title: Inadequate guidance for implementation
sec.p:
The participants shared multiple approaches to interacting with women with diabetes. They inferred that the differences in practices stem from insufficient training among doctors and support staff. The lack of standard guidelines worsens this issue.
“For me, I have not had any training in PCC and my knowledge about all these contraception is very poor, so I’m not very comfortable doing this kind of counselling” [Dr M, urban clinic].

They also noted that diabetes training assigns less focus to PCC, and diabetic educators, who play a crucial role in the diabetes programme, do not receive targeted training in PCC during their advanced specialty education training. Nurse F, a diabetic educator emphasised the need for PCC training in diabetes.
“.,. we are not really trained. There isn’t any input (on PCC) during the 6 months of DE (diabetic educator) training. It’s more of a general input. I think we really ought to have training on PCC because we need to know the flow of delivery”. [Nurse F, urban clinic]

Some participants shared that inadequate structured supervision by higher health authorities also contributes to the challenges in PCC training. Dr K highlighted that the continuous medical education in PCC ceases when the higher administrative office stops monitoring the training schedule. This is in contrast with the diabetes programme, where the quality improvement process is structured and continuously monitored.
“No more demand, so we stop. We only send in the diabetic data, JKN (the State Health Department) is no longer checking, so don’t really care how it is done.”. [Dr K, FMS, urban clinic]

Additionally, the participants, especially the MOs, were not following a standard guideline when providing PCC to women with diabetes. Regardless of the clinic location, some participants had not come across any standard general or specific guideline on PCC.
“There is no guideline to assist with PCC and family planning”. [Dr L, urban clinic]

Consequently, the PCC delivery was tailored to fit the clinic’s culture and the preferences of staff, especially nurses. They offered care and communicated information about PCC based on their personal understanding.
“No SOP (standard operating procedure). We do our own”. [Nurse J, rural clinic]
“Usually, we follow what seniors taught us, so it’s more like a culture of the clinic. But the way we do it, the way we counsel is very much individual.” [Dr O, urban clinic].

sec.title: Lack of gender-personalised PCC
sec.p:
The participants noted that personalised PCC cannot be delivered consistently, even with the family doctor concept meant to ensure continuity of care from the beginning. The system was not designed to meet women’s expectations for gender-personalised care. The current healthcare system randomly assigns any doctor to any patient regardless of gender, illness or complaint. This affects the disclosure of sensitive issues, such as pregnancy and family planning.
“ Sometimes a female patient requires a female doctor to talk about sensitive issues. But our system doesn’t allow patients to request doctors.” [Nurse L, rural clinic].

The participants felt that patients prefer female doctors for discussing pregnancy-related issues, which limits male doctors’ exposure to these topics. Additionally, the requirement for a chaperone for a male doctor during consultations can prevent the disclosure of sensitive matters. Dr. R, a male medical officer, admitted to having barriers when discussing PCC.
“Pregnancy planning,.it didn’t cross my mind. I will need to have a chaperon, we have barriers with that, and nine years of experience, they have never asked me (pregnancy), probably because they are more comfortable with female doctors. ” [Dr R, senior doctor, urban clinic].

sec.title: Theme 2: healthcare provider (HCP) factors
sec.p: Participants revealed that HCP factors present significant challenges to the effective implementation of PCC. HCPs’ personal and professional values, including their attitudes toward PCC, religious beliefs, and gaps in gender sensitivity, influenced how care is delivered. Additionally, inadequate knowledge and team dynamics further undermine the quality and effectiveness of PCC.

sec.title: HCP attitudes toward PCC
sec.p:
The participants identified certain personal factors, including being male, impatience, and a lackadaisical attitude towards PCC, as reasons for the lack of PCC provided to women with diabetes. However, one of the participants expressed that having a strong personality does not always align with the expected positive professional consultation.
“I’m not a very patient doctor. I want to settle things very fast, sometimes maybe my voice also is not soft. I don’t get women telling me about reproductive issues”. [Dr M, urban clinic]

Additionally, attitude plays a crucial supportive role in maintaining the continuity of patient care. Dr. Z noted that some doctors appeared to lack enthusiasm and commitment in delivering patient care.

“Reason (for the lack of PCC) is you are not responsible for your own patients…because you (transit doctors) are not seeing your patients again .so you feel like someone else will settle this…Very lackadaisical!” [Dr Z, urban clinic].

sec.title: Influence of personal or religious beliefs
sec.p:
One of the participants in one of the FGDs indicated that the religious beliefs of HCP influence the provision of personalised PCC. During that session, the rest of the FGD members just nodded, but nobody contested or verbally agreed.
“ To say ligation, because it’s permanent and the challenge for me is, more of religiosity…I’m a Muslim, and as Muslims, we are encouraged to have more kids. I think I’m blocking those things if I suggest ligation.” [ Dr F, rural clinic].

He then shared how he internalised his conflicts,
“But then I think the benefit outweighs the risk. I think in Islam, as long as it doesn’t harm mother and child, it is fine.” [ Dr F, rural clinic].

sec.title: Knowledge and team dynamics
sec.p: Participants revealed that knowledge and team dynamics are crucial factors impacting the implementation of PCC. Many healthcare providers lack expertise and skills related to PCC, often rely on non-holistic clinical approaches, and faced challenges with teamwork and collaboration. These gaps have hindered the delivery of coordinated, patient-centered care and limited the effectiveness of PCC in clinical practice.

sec.title: Insufficient PCC-related expertise
sec.p:
Participants also highlighted that many HCPs lack sufficient knowledge and practical experience with PCC, which is important for effectively practicing PCC. Junior doctors with less experience in healthcare may not be well-equipped to counsel on PCC.
“In my opinion, the senior doctors have no problem (with PCC) due to the knowledge and experience they have in the primary care, but I think it will be a problem for the juniors. They are not really exposed.” [Dr U urban clinic].
“I’m a junior doctor, so it will be a bit scary because I don’t really know, not really sure about what to do in clinic care in PCC.” [Dr E a junior doctor, urban clinic].

Inadequate knowledge and skills undermine doctors’ confidence in providing personalised contraceptive counselling, leading to feelings of insecurity. As a result, counselling often becomes rigid and doctor-centered, reflecting a need for improved training and greater flexibility in approach.

“The doctors would say you are already on it for two years and would risk getting osteoporosis, but still force her to take…very rigid. I don’t know why. A lot of wrong information.”[Dr I, senior doctor, urban clinic].

sec.title: Non-holistic clinical approach
sec.p:
Participants note that healthcare professionals recognise the importance of a holistic approach in treating women with diabetes. However, in daily consultations, the busy clinic setting often hampers this approach, resulting in neglect of patients’ reproductive needs.
“When a reproductive age woman comes, first we have to ask LMP (menstrual date). Then, whether they want to get pregnant or not. We either forget or miss, somehow, we tend to concentrate on why they come, (diabetes)…That is why we tend to miss this (PCC).” [Dr U, urban clinic].

HCPs also have preconceived ideas regarding older women being less inclined to conceive.
“We don’t really advise women after 40 not to get pregnant. I think I have that culture too.40 plus rarely get pregnant.” [Dr V, urban clinic].

Communication skill is an essential value in managing PCC holistically. It has been observed that some doctors are inclined towards a paternalistic type of communication.
“It was not really counselling. The one I heard…the doctor didn’t even ask whether the patient wanted to get pregnant or not. Just one way of communication.” [Dr K, FMS, rural clinic].

sec.title: Lack of teamwork and collaboration
sec.p:
Another challenge identified by the participants in providing PCC was the lack of teamwork among HCPs. Many HCPs are not fully aware of the role of each team member in implementing PCC.
“The nurses are not doing anything (PCC). Not here. Only the doctors.”[Dr J, urban clinic].

Miscommunication among ground-level sub-units further worsens service delivery. The absence of effective teamwork ultimately leads to poor information sharing about PCC among staff. Nurse R, responsible for managing the PCC form locally, faces difficulties in consolidating the PCC information provided to patients.

“Sometimes, the PCC form came out empty. I don’t know what to say. Maybe they (doctors) wanted to be fast …the form is already clipped at the front page, maybe they just flip and see what they need to do…a lot are like that.” [Nurse R, urban clinic].

sec.title: Theme 3: Patient-related factors
sec.p: Participants revealed that patient-related factors also affect the delivery of PPC. These factors include low health literacy and inadequate pregnancy planning among women with diabetes. Additionally, religious, social, and economic influences greatly impact patients’ access to care.

sec.title: Poor pregnancy planning among women with diabetes
sec.p: The participants indicated that dealing with the obstinacy of women towards pregnancy planning was another challenge in the implementation of PCC.

“Despite the PCC screening, patients still got pregnant unplanned. So we can’t assume what we say is perceived well by them. Oh! Different people have different levels of processing facts”. [Nurse J, rural clinic]

sec.title: General health illiteracy
sec.p:
Health literacy among women with diabetes influences their acceptance of contraception. These women fail to comprehend the seriousness of pregnancy in cases of uncontrolled diabetes. The doctors echoed similar frustration over these women’s refusal to use effective methods, as they often prefer traditional approaches.
“They don’t believe in modern contraception, so they do their own protection … myth of contraception. They said, the new contraception will cause them to become infertile if taken for quite some time”. [Dr J, urban clinic]
Concerns about side effects and the requirement for strict adherence contribute to this hesitation.

“They don’t take contraception because they don’t want to get fat. Hormonal contraception can cause weight gain. Intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) causes pain; it’s not comfortable when having sex.” [Dr T, urban clinic].

sec.title: Impact of religious, social, and economic factors on care access
sec.p:
This study showed that women with diabetes were hesitant about contraception because of their religious beliefs, viewing events as God’s will. They believe that pregnancy, seen as a route to a good life, should not be interfered with, which results in a lack of planning for pregnancy despite recognising the risks involved.
“.They know the problems during pregnancy but they become like, if pregnant so be it. No preparation. No effort to control. Just leave it to fate, like god’s gift right”. [Dr A, rural clinic]

The spouses influence similar attitudes regarding pregnancy planning.
“They said that their husband disapproves (of contraception). They say children are “rezeki (gifts)”. There is no need to plan.” [Dr K, FMS, rural clinic].

In rural areas, planning for pregnancy is not a common practice. Traditional cultural norms do not incorporate pregnancy planning concept, making it unfamiliar to these women.
“In rural areas, when it comes to pregnancy and co-morbidities, they’re more concerned about pregnancy, not about the co-morbidities. They want a child, forget about the underlying problem…even though the awareness is there, but you know the traditional way is in them.” [Dr N, rural clinic].

The participants identified socioeconomic constraints as significant factors contributing to poor adherence to treatment regimens. Women with diabetes struggle to manage their condition effectively due to insufficient social and infrastructure support in accessing healthcare and maintaining their livelihoods. They may not get support from their husband, in-laws, or workplace.
”Dr, I can’t come that frequently. I have children at home, in-laws to care for. So they find ways to simplify the whole process. They don’t get support.”. [Dr U, urban clinic]

Logistics pose a major obstacle to healthcare, particularly for indigenous communities.
“The orang Asli cannot come to Klink Desa (rural health clinic) because they live very remotely, and for them to come here is very difficult. By the time they come, sometimes they are 20 weeks already pregnant”. [Dr G, rural clinic]

Additionally, the costs of managing their chronic conditions and attending clinic visits are burdensome, leading them to prioritise economic activities over their well-being.
“Too many follow-ups, and she cannot afford to come frequently. She’s a babysitter. So if she wanted to come, she needs to inform all six mothers, they might find a new babysitter, she needs the money, so she would rather not come.” [Dr J, urban clinic].

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study explored the challenges faced by HCPs when providing preconception care (PCC) to women with diabetes, who carry high risks for poor pregnancy outcomes. Theme 1 highlights that PCC was not fully integrated into Malaysia’s healthcare system, particularly in the management of diabetes, one of the country’s leading non-communicable diseases. Despite significant efforts to optimise diabetes management, the study indicates that PCC remains an underrepresented component within the diabetes care pathway. Additionally, the findings underscore the urgent need to create an environment conducive to personalised care, emphasising its importance for improved health outcomes. Theme 2 describes how HCPs’ personal values can affect their approach to women’s reproductive issues with diabetes. It also highlights how the work culture, which sometimes did not align with the recommended standards of professionalism in medicine, played a role in influencing their management strategies. Theme 3 illustrated how the women’s lack of pregnancy planning impacted HCPs’ approach to PCC among these women. HCPs often deemed PCC unnecessary if the women did not bring up related concerns. These factors shaped HCPs’ considerations on PCC for women with diabetes.

Our findings reveal that PCC is not systematically embedded within existing diabetes management programs in Malaysia, resulting in missed opportunities for early intervention and comprehensive care. This is consistent with studies from the UK and the US, where PCC for women with diabetes is often poorly integrated into routine care, leading to low uptake and suboptimal outcomes [16, 17]. For example, a UK qualitative study found that both general practitioners (GPs) and secondary care professionals recognised the lack of clear policies and guidelines as a barrier to effective PCC delivery, echoing the need for better integration and clearer division of responsibilities between primary and secondary care [17]. The healthcare system is integral to achieving an excellent outcome in any health program. A well-coordinated PCC service for women with diabetes is recognised as an important component of primary care delivery [18]. Coordinated care is provider- and payer-centric, assisting patients in navigating the complex health system at different levels of care; whereas, care integration is more person-centric, focusing on developing better strategies to deliver care for improved outcomes [19]. Malaysia needs both a coordinated and integrated PCC for women with diabetes especially in the primary care setting. Primary care providers are ideally positioned to manage reproductive-aged women with diabetes before, between, and after their pregnancies [6]. Therefore, it is beneficial to incorporate components of PCC into various areas of diabetes care, such as routine diabetic management and existing family planning services [20]. This is reported by a Dutch study, which emphasises that an integrated PCC programme is essential to ensure the successful delivery of PCC [21].

Similar to our situation, international studies have reported that diabetes care, reproductive health, and family planning services are often delivered in silos, resulting in fragmented care [17, 22]. In providing quality service in an organised, effective, and efficient manner to women with chronic diseases, all levels of care must be coordinated concurrently and not operate in silos [22]. This is supported by the three pillars of good integration of care: (1) identify a shared vision and community, (2) leverage shared platforms, and (3) work towards shared alignment of incentives and accountability [19]. Rhyming the general diabetes care, PCC, and family planning for women with diabetes will encourage HCPs and patients to share their vision on a common platform. However, it has been recognised by others and in this study that care fragmentation is a challenge in managing women with diabetes [22]. Women with diabetes have also expressed concerns about the lack of collaboration among various healthcare departments and the challenges posed by different levels within healthcare facilities [10]. The lack of communication between HCPs at various levels appears to stem from the structure of the healthcare system itself and is a well-known issue among HCPs [23]. Providing PCC should ideally be integrated into routine care rather than offered as a specialised service. However, this presents significant challenges due to the need for multidisciplinary collaboration [18]. A local survey of family physicians revealed a preference for integrating personalised care into public healthcare clinic services [24], presenting an opportunity to include PCC in the management of diabetes for the general population.

The lack of prioritisation of PCC in organisational key performance index (KPI) is not unique to Malaysia. Studies from high-income countries also noted that, despite evidence supporting the effectiveness of PCC, it is often not a measured or incentivised aspect of care [25, 26]. The absence of robust electronic medical records (EMR) is a significant barrier in the current setting. Medical audits and quality improvement efforts have shown that systematically documenting PCC pregnancy risks in an EMR can significantly assist doctors in delivering optimal PCC, an effort to improve the quality of care [27, 28]. Incomplete documentation of reproductive health risks is ineffective data and reduces the chances of offering comprehensive PCC [29]. Technological tools, with an emphasis on the use of EMR, are crucial for sharing information between necessary stakeholders to facilitate communication within and between different levels of care, thereby providing good documentation [30]. EMR is a comprehensive data source that records all preconception health risk factors. However, it can only be effectively used for assessment if the data is complete [28, 31]. When supported by thorough documentation in the EMR, it can act as a checklist to ensure that all essential areas of care are covered [32]. Even GPs and nurses consider EMR to be a valid and practical tool for identifying preconception health risks [33]. Nonetheless, a significant challenge cited by numerous institutions is the initial investment and ongoing maintenance costs [34], highlighting the vital role of public health authorities in coordinating these services. Furthermore, healthcare organisations must ensure the safety and confidentiality of patient information within the EMR system [34].

Our findings, that HCPs lack clear, practical guidelines for integrating PCC into existing workflows, are mirrored in other studies. A UK study, for instance, found that GPs and other healthcare providers cited a need for more explicit protocols and support to deliver PCC effectively [17]. The lack of standardised guidelines leads to inconsistent practices and missed intervention opportunities. Developing and implementing clear guidelines, along with strategies to enhance PCC awareness, is crucial for achieving full PCC adoption and improving HCPs’ knowledge [35]. In regard to infrastructure, there is a lack of dedicated spaces for PCC in our public health clinics, along with no established framework for gender-personalised PCC services, which can compromise privacy and the quality of care. Similar resource constraints have been reported in another low- and middle-income country, where limited infrastructure hinder the delivery of comprehensive diabetes and reproductive health services [37]. Having adequate consultation spaces that respect women’s privacy may promote the uptake of PCC service [10, 26]. Addressing these resource shortages requires policy, financial, and political advocacy [36], which can pose significant challenges to providing high-quality PCC.

Our findings showed that HCPs factors greatly influence the delivery of PCC to women with diabetes. Major barriers include limited knowledge and expertise in PCC, non-holistic clinical approaches, and poor teamwork and collaboration. While gaining PCC-related knowledge is often seen as an individual responsibility, participants in this study as well as those reported in other studies, point to systemic factors like limited training, minimal exposure to women’s health, and staffing shortages as reasons for these gaps [22–26] Evidence also suggests that rapid training alone is inadequate to change clinical practice, highlighting the need for broader improvements in healthcare resources, care flow, and documentation, as well as promotional activities to enhance PCC uptake [10].

In terms of patient-related factors, participants attributed poor engagement with PCC to women’s lack of familiarity and understanding of pregnancy planning, limited health literacy, sociocultural background, and economic constraint. Personal health literacy refers to the extent to which individuals can locate, comprehend, and utilise information and services to make informed health decisions for themselves and others [37]. An earlier local study found that only 31% of women with diabetes used effective contraception to prevent pregnancy, despite over 65% recognising their risk of pregnancy-related complications [38]. Having positive attitudes towards PCC also plays a role, not just health literacy, as evidenced by a study that shows, despite optimal health literacy, the uptake of some components of PCC was low [39]. In addition, some women with diabetes who do not intend to become pregnant often perceive a lower risk of pregnancy and see less need for pregnancy planning, which can cause a delay in actively planning for pregnancy [40]. This remains a significant reproductive health issue for women with diabetes that needs to be addressed within the PCC framework.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: To the best of our knowledge, this is one of the first qualitative studies exploring the challenges and barriers experienced or observed by HCPs when delivering PCC for women with diabetes in public health clinics in Malaysia. Other local studies have evaluated PCC, but in a more general context or studies involving patients. The findings of our study offer more in-depth insights into the delivery of PCC for women with chronic diseases, potentially informing the development of strategies to overcome these barriers. This study also presents perspectives not only from doctors but also from nurses and AMOs, emphasising similar challenges and thereby enhancing the trustworthiness of the data. The generalisability of this study is limited, as the findings reflect only the views and experiences of HCPs in public health clinics, and not those from private clinics or from either government nor private hospital settings. These institutions may differ in patients’ sociocultural and economic background, system infrastructure, and resource accessibility, which may result in varied views and experiences regarding PCC services. Future studies should explore the perspectives of policymakers or key stakeholders in reproductive health to develop a pragmatic approach to improve PCC services in the country.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study highlights the gaps involving organisations, HCPs, and factors influencing women with diabetes that must be addressed when implementing PCC for these women, especially given the high prevalence of diabetes in the country and its serious complications if not properly managed. Instead of segregating management within similar healthcare facilities, a more effective approach could involve consolidating resources to address manpower, space, and infrastructure challenges. Equally important is providing adequate training for HCPs to enhance care quality and improve health literacy among women with diabetes. Successful implementation relies on effective engagement between HCPs and the women. In this way, PCC can be recognised as a vital component of the healthcare system for diabetes management in the country. Additionally, this approach can be adapted for women with other chronic conditions.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors would like to extend their gratitude to the Ministry of Health for granting permission to conduct this study and to Universiti Malaya for the funding.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: The entire research team contributed to the design of the study. The leading researcher collected all the data. All researchers initially analysed and interpreted the first three sets of transcripts. Subsequently, the lead researcher continued with the analysis, while the entire team provided independent reviews of the data interpretation. All authors collaboratively reviewed, revised, and approved the final manuscript.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This study was funded by the Postgraduate Research Fund, vote number PG282-2016 A, and the awarding body has no role in the study design, data collection, data analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: In view of the nature of qualitative study, there would be an issue of confidentiality; hence, the data cannot be made readily available to the public. However, the data are available upon reasonable request to the corresponding author, provided permission is obtained from Universiti Malaya, Malaysia.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
notes.p: This study was approved by the National Medical Research Ethics Committee, Ministry of Health (NMRR ID:16-385-29240). Written informed consent was taken for participation in the study and publication. Participation in the study was voluntary. The study was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki.

notes.title: Consent for publication
notes.p: Consent to publish was obtained from the participants of this study to publish de-identified data.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
